ALLEGATION#1:
Foster Child A was removed from Foster Parent A without notice or the right to a
Foster Care Review Board (FCRB) appeal. The agency violated Foster Parent A’s
Foster Parent Bill of Rights.
ALLEGATION#2:
Foster Child A was returned to her father’s care despite his pending criminal
charges and Foster Child A’s pediatrician’s recommendation. Foster Child A’s
return to her father’s care violated the Referee’s order.
INVESTIGATION:
I reviewed the Complainant’s letter on February 23, 2021. The letter stated Foster Child
A was placed in her father’s care, who has a significant history of domestic violence,
criminal offenses of a sexual nature, controlled substance abuse and suicidal attempts
or threats. The letter stated Ennis Center for Children returned Foster Child A under the
guise of reunification with Foster Child A’s father by arranging a stipulated order to
remove Foster Child A from Foster Parent A and reunify her with her father. The
Complainant stated reunification occurred before either Foster Child A’s parents
completed necessary services, showed stability, the ability to support themselves or
Foster Child A and before the resolution of outstanding sexual offense charges pending
against Foster Child A’s father. The letter reported Foster Child A’s pediatrician urged
Ennis Center for Children to stop the reunification with Foster Child A’s father and at the
very least until the felony charges are resolved.
I interviewed MDHHS Worker 1 via telephone on February 25, 2021. She reported
Foster Child A’s father was not involved in the beginning of the case because Foster
Child A’s mother did not disclose Foster Child A’s father’s name. She stated Foster
Child A’s lawyer guardian ad litem (LGAL) motioned for Foster Child A to return to her
father’s care. She said the court signed an order returning Foster Child A to her father’s
care and the case is now being serviced by the Intensive Neglect Services Program
(INS) via Ingham County.
I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief Administrator, Ennis Center for
Children - Pontiac Howell's Satellite Office Director, Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac
Foster Care Worker 1 and Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Supervisor 1
face-to-face on-site on March 04, 2021. Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care
Worker 1 reported she received an email from Foster Child A’s LGAL on November 16,
2020 at 3:01 p.m., which included the court order placing Foster Child A with her father.
She said she emailed the court order to Foster Parent A, along with their attorney,
within an hour of receiving the court order and informed them that Foster Child A was
now placed in the care and custody of her father. She said she also mailed Foster
Parent A a MDHHS-30 Notification of Move form on November 16, 2020. She stated
4

Foster Child A was removed without advance notice to Foster Parent A because she
was not made aware that a stipulation order was submitted by Foster Child A’s LGAL
until after it was submitted and signed by the judge. She reported the following timeline
of events leading up to the court order placing Foster Child A with her father:
 On November 12, 2020 at 11:05 p.m., Foster Child A’s mother texted Foster
Care Worker 1 informing her that she would need to cancel her parenting time for
November 13, 2020 due to having car trouble. Foster Care Worker 1 reported
Foster Child A’s father’s parenting time was every week from Friday after Foster
Child A’s mother’s parenting time until the following Tuesday. Foster Parent A, at
their request, would transport Foster Child A to a third-party location near Foster
Child A’s father’s home. Foster Care Worker 1 said she supervised all pick-up
and drop-offs.
 Foster Care Worker 1 attempted two phone calls with Foster Parent A and a text
message to inform them that the visit for Foster Child A’s was cancelled and
Foster Care Worker 1 would need to figure out a time for Foster Child A to be
dropped off with her father. She reported she left a voicemail requesting a return
phone call each time. She reported Foster Parent A did not return her phone
calls.
 On November 13, 2020 at 10:49 a.m., Foster Care Worker 1 received an email
from Foster Parent A stating they had serious reservations about having Foster
Child A participate in a five-day, four-night overnight visitation with another
household, in another household. Foster Parent A stated in the email that they
looked forward to resuming visitations once the Governor issued an “all clear.”
Foster Care Worker 1 reported she forwarded Foster Parent A’s email to all
parties involved with the case.
 On November 13, 2020 at 12:06 p.m., Foster Child A’s LGAL emailed the parties
involved in the case and indicated Foster Child A’s father’s parenting time must
occur, and if it does not occur, then she would seek next steps with the
prosecutor’s office.
 On November 13, 2020 at 12:11 p.m., Foster Care Worker 1 received an email
from Foster Child A’s LGAL stating that it was time to move Foster Child A.
Foster Care Worker 1 reported that the statement was regarding Foster Parent
A’s refusal to allow parenting time to occur with Foster Child A’s father and
regarding their complaint letter to Ennis Center for Children providing additional
barriers for reunification.
 On November 13, 2020 at 1:33 p.m., Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief
Administrator voiced his concerns and opposition, via email, regarding Foster
Child A being placed with her father due to his pending criminal charges.
 On November 16, 2020 at 3:01 p.m., Foster Child A’s LGAL emailed Foster Care
Worker 1 the court order placing Foster Child A in the care of Foster Child A’s
father. The court order was signed on November 13, 2020.
Foster Care Worker 1 stated per 2004 PA 46, if the court has ordered that the child is
returned home, the foster parents do not have the right to an appeal. She reported
Ennis Center for Children did not recommend Foster Child A to be placed with her
father. She stated the stipulation to place child with Foster Child A’s father and
5

modification of Foster Child A’s parenting time was submitted by the prosecutor, Foster
Child A’s LGAL, Foster Child A’s mother’s attorney, and Foster Child A’s father’s
attorney. The judge signed the order on November 13, 2020. Foster Care Worker 1
stated on October 5, 2020, she provided the court with Foster Child A’s arrest record
and Foster Child A’s notes, including a letter by Physician 1 following Foster Child A’s
Sexual Assault Nurse Exam (SANE) for the October 13, 2020 court hearing. She
reported the information was provided to and received by all court parties, including the
judge and referee. She denied violating any court order.
I reviewed documents provided by Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac on March 8, 2021,
March 9, 2021, March 11, 2021, March 15, 2021, March 16, 2021 and April 7, 2021.
The documents included the following:
 The emails that were outlined in Foster Care Worker 1’s timeline of events
leading to the placement of Foster Child A with her father were reviewed and
were consistent with her timeline.
 The stipulation and order to place child with respondent father and modify
parenting time of respondent mother was signed by the prosecutor, Foster Child
A’s LGAL, Foster Child A’s mother’s attorney, Foster Child A’s father’s attorney
and judge on November 13, 2020. It was ordered to place Foster Child A in the
care of her father and the parenting time of the mother was modified.
 The MDHHS-30 Foster Parent Notification of Move was signed by Foster Care
Worker 1 and Foster Care Supervisor 1 on November 16, 2020.
 The email that was sent to the court on October 5, 2020, which included Foster
Child A’s pediatrician notes, foster care service plans and Foster Child A’s
criminal records, was consistent with Foster Care Worker 1’s interview.
APPLICABLE RULE
MDHHS 722-03D Placement Change
A child’s placement may not be changed prior to providing
the caregiver notice and opportunity to appeal the
placement change unless:
• The foster parent/caregiver requests the child be moved.
• The court with jurisdiction orders the child to return home.
• The change in placement is less than 30 calendar days
after the child's initial removal from his or her home.
• The change in placement is less than 90 calendar days
after the initial placement and the new placement is with a
relative.
A caregiver has the right to appeal the placement change
under the following circumstances:
• The supervising agency has reasonable cause to believe
that the child has suffered sexual abuse or non-accidental
physical injury, or there is substantial risk of harm to the
6

child's emotional well-being or physical safety within the
caregiver's home.
• It is determined that it is in the child's best interest to be
moved.
Foster Care and Foster parent's bill of rights law; rights; grievance
Adoption procedure; hearing; remedy; complaint; report;
Services Act 203 investigations subject to appropriation of funds.
of 1994 Sec. 8a. (o)
722.958a
Advance notice of a child's move from a foster home in
order to prepare the child and foster family members. The
advance notice required in this subdivision does not apply
in a case of an emergency situation when there is evidence
of mistreatment as provided in section 13b(7) of chapter
XIIA of the probate code of 1939, 1939 PA 288, MCL
712A.13b, or when the court orders a child to be moved
from a foster home but does not allow for advance notice.
ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to show that Ennis Center for
Children-Pontiac is in violation of MDHHS 722-03D Placement
Change and Foster Care and Adoption Services Act 203 of
1994 722.958a. Foster Care Worker 1 provided documentation
to the court and all the parties involved with the case regarding
Foster Child A’s father’s criminal record and the
recommendation letter from Foster Child A’s pediatrician on
October 5, 2020 for the October 13, 2020 court hearing. There
is no documentation that Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac
recommended the placement of Foster Child A with her father.
Foster Parent A was not provided with advance notice of the
move because Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac did not submit
the stipulation to place Foster Child A with her father. Foster
Child A’s LGAL submitted a stipulation to place Foster Child A
with her father on November 13, 2020. Foster Care Worker 1
received the placement order on November 16, 2020 and she
notified Foster Parent A and their attorney the same day. Foster
Care Worker 1 mailed the MDHHS-30 Foster Parent Notification
of Move form to Foster Parent A on November 16, 2020.
Per MDHHS policy, Foster Parent A does not have the right to
appeal the placement change to the Foster Care Review Board
because the court ordered Foster Child A to be placed in the
care of her father.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing
of the following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the
change, except when prior notification would jeopardize the
child's care or safety. If prior notice is not provided, then
the agency shall notify the foster parent, at the time of the
change, why prior notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent's rights concerning
the change in placement.
ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to show that Ennis Center for
Children-Pontiac is in violation of MDHHS 722-03D Placement
Change and Foster Care and Adoption Services Act 203 of
1994 722.958a. Foster Care Worker 1 provided documentation
to the court and all the parties involved with the case regarding
Foster Child A’s father’s criminal record and the
recommendation letter from Foster Child A’s pediatrician on
October 5, 2020 for the October 13, 2020 court hearing. There
is no documentation that Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac
recommended the placement of Foster Child A with her father.
Foster Parent A was not provided with advance notice of the
move because Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac did not submit
the stipulation to place Foster Child A with her father. Foster
Child A’s LGAL submitted a stipulation to place Foster Child A
with her father on November 13, 2020. Foster Care Worker 1
received the placement order on November 16, 2020 and she
notified Foster Parent A and their attorney the same day. Foster
Care Worker 1 mailed the MDHHS-30 Foster Parent Notification
of Move form to Foster Parent A on November 16, 2020.
Per MDHHS policy, Foster Parent A does not have the right to
appeal the placement change to the Foster Care Review Board
because the court ordered Foster Child A to be placed in the
care of her father.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
8

ALLEGATION#3:
Foster Parent 1 was not provided written notice of the court proceedings. They
were not given court reports despite being told by MDHHS Foster Care POS
Supervisor 1 that they are entitled to the court reports.
INVESTIGATION:
I reviewed the Complainant’s letter on February 23, 2021. The letter stated Foster
Parent A was not provided required written notice of court proceedings and Ennis
Center for Children withheld court reports from them while they were Foster Child A’s
foster parent. The letter stated although MDHHS Foster Care POS Supervisor 1 made it
clear that Foster Parent A were entitled to the court reports, Foster Care Worker 1 still
refused to provide them, telling Foster Parent A, “the only way they could learn of what
was going on was to attend the hearings.”
I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief Administrator, Ennis Center for
Children - Pontiac Howell's Satellite Office Director, Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac
Foster Care Worker 1, and Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Supervisor 1
face-to-face on-site on March 04, 2021. Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care
Worker 1 reported Foster Parent A attended all court proceedings and were present to
receive information about the next court date. Foster Care Worker 1 reported she
provided Foster Parent A with court hearing information, which included the date, time,
and Zoom information, via email on June 1, 2020, September 1, 2020, and October 13,
2020. She said Foster Parent A is also mailed notice of court hearings with each court
hearing as their address has been provided to the court.
I reviewed documents provided by Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac on March 8, 2021,
March 9, 2021, March 11, 2021, March 15, 2021, March 16, 2021, and April 7, 2021.
The documents included the following:
 Foster Parent A was documented as being present for court hearings on Ennis
Center for Children court hearing disposition forms dated November 7, 2019,
January 7, 2020, January 16, 2020, March 18, 2020, June 3, 2020, September 2,
2020, and October 14, 2020.
 Foster Care Worker 1 emailed Foster Parent A on May 29, 2020 the date, time
and Zoom information for the June 2, 2020 court hearing.
 Foster Care Worker 1 emailed Foster Parent A on August 26, 2020 the date, time
and Zoom information for the September 1, 2020 court hearing.
I reviewed Foster Child A’s case in MiSACWIS on April 13, 2021. Court hearings for
Foster Child A were completed on the following dates: April 18, 2019, May 9, 2019,
August 6, 2019, October 15, 2019, December 19, 2019, January 7, 2020, January 16,
2020, March 17, 2020, April 27, 2020, May 9, 2020, June 2, 2020, September 1, 2020,
September 11, 2020, and October 13, 2020.
9

APPLICABLE RULE
MDHHS Policy Court Hearing Notification Requirements.
FOM 722-10
State and federal law requires courts to ensure that certain
parties are notified of proceedings held with respect to a
child under the jurisdiction of the court. To facilitate this
process the supervising agency is required to provide
notification of all court proceedings to the following:
• The child, if the child is 11 years or older.
• The foster parents, relative caregivers, and/or pre-
adoptive parents.
• The non-offending parent if the child is placed with that
parent.
If the court provides notice of hearing to the caseworker in
a timely manner, the caseworker must send the DHS 715,
Notice of Hearing, to the child, foster parents, relative
caregivers, the non-offending parent, and/or pre-adoptive
parents seven calendar days prior to the hearing.
ANALYSIS: Based on documents provided by Ennis Center for Children-
Pontiac and information reviewed in MiSACWIS, there is
sufficient evidence to show that Ennis Center for Children-
Pontiac is in violation of this policy. The agency did not provide
Foster Parent A written notice at least seven calendar days prior
to the court hearings which were held on April 18, 2019, May 9,
2019, August 6, 2019, October 15, 2019, December 19, 2019,
January 7, 2020, January 16, 2020, March 17, 2020, April 27,
2020, May 9, 2020, September 11, 2020, and October 13, 2020.
The policy does not indicate that caseworkers are required to
provide court reports to the child, foster parents, relative
caregivers, the non-offending parent, and/or pre-adoptive
parents.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION#4:
Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac did not include Foster Parent 1 in case
planning or ensure that their input and written statements were provided to the
court.
10

INVESTIGATION:
I reviewed the Complainant’s letter on February 23, 2021. The letter stated Ennis
Center for Children did not include Foster Parent A in the case planning nor did Ennis
Center for Children inform Foster Parent A their ability to offer their input and written
statements directly to the court at each hearing.
I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief Administrator, Ennis Center for
Children - Pontiac Howell's Satellite Office Director, Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac
Foster Care Worker 1, and Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Supervisor 1
face-to-face on-site on March 04, 2021. Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care
Worker 1 stated Foster Parent A was invited to all Family Team Meetings (FTMs)
unless Foster Child A’s parents requested that they not be present at the FTMs. She
said Foster Parent A was invited via email to the FTMs completed on May 29, 2020,
June 10, 2020, September 14, 2020, and November 19, 2020. She reported she
provided the court with letters from Foster Child A’s pediatrician for the October 13,
2020 court hearing containing Foster Parent A’s concerns. She stated that foster
parents were provided with all redacted updated service plans (USPs) and parent
agency treatment plans (PATPs). Foster Care Worker 1 reported Foster Parent A
frequently brought their concerns to the agency and the concerns were addressed with
the family. She stated Foster Parent A would frequently write letters to the court
regarding their concerns and they were submitted to the court. Foster Care Worker 1
reported Foster Parent A would provide the agency with limited responses during home
visits. She said the family would not advise the agency of their concerns during home
visits and throughout the case they would bring their concerns to the court and MDHHS.
She said each time, the concerns were addressed.
Foster Care Worker 1 stated occasionally, the referee provided Foster Parent A with an
opportunity to speak at court hearings. She said at the October 13, 2020 court hearing,
Foster Parent A’s attorney was able to provide a brief and was able to address the court
on the record on behalf of the family. Foster Care Worker 1 stated she had to stop
allowing Foster Parent A to supervise parenting time for Foster Child A’s mother
because the foster parents would not provide Foster Care Worker 1 information related
to when the parenting time occurred and their observations during the parenting time.
When she asked Foster Parent A to provide the information, they refused to provide it to
her. Foster Care Worker 1 stated Foster Parent A would not always involve Foster
Care Worker 1 in decision making and would not always bring forth their concerns. She
said when Foster Parent A had concerns that Foster Child A had been sexually abused,
they did not contact Child Protective Services, advise Foster Care Worker 1 or Foster
Child A’s LGAL instead Foster Parent A had a SANE exam performed on Foster Child
A. She said the SANE exam was done without the consent or knowledge of Ennis
Center for Children and Foster Child A’s parents. Foster Care Worker 1 reported Foster
Parent A would not provide Foster Care Worker 1 with information regarding medical
and dental visits when asked and would only do so once the visit had occurred,
therefore, making it impossible for Foster Child A’s parents to attend the visits.
11

Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief Administrator reported on January 14, 2020, he
provided Foster Parent A with a written response to the letter they submitted to the
agency on November 22, 2019. He said the letter included concerns about the agency
and about Foster Child A’s father. The Chief Administrator stated he, Foster Care
Worker 1 and MDHHS Foster Care POS Supervisor 1 met with Foster Parent A at
MDHHS to discuss and address the concerns. He reported as a result of the meeting,
Foster Care Worker 1 agreed to the following: Foster Care Worker 1 would send a
letter, a text message, and an email containing the parenting time schedule, Foster
Care Worker 1 would primarily use written communication to communicate with Foster
Parent A; Foster Parent A would be provided with all USPs and PATPs, and all
parenting time would be held at Ingham County MDHHS, as Foster Parent A did not
want to transport Foster Child A to Ennis Center for Children’s Howell satellite office. He
reported to accommodate Foster Parent A’s request for parenting visits in Ingham
County, all parenting time was moved to Ingham County despite Foster Child A’s
mother residing in Genesee County and Foster Child A’s father preferring that the
parenting time be held at the Howell satellite office.
I reviewed documents provided by Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac on March 8, 2021,
March 9, 2021, March 11, 2021, March 15, 2021, March 16, 2021, and April 7, 2021.
The documents included the following:
 The letter dated November 22, 2019 and written by Foster Parent A included
their recollection of how Foster Child A’s first visit with her father went. The letter
stated Ennis Center for Children has not always prepared documentation timely
for court, completed family planning meetings and reports not being prepared
and/or filed with the court. The letter also expressed their concerns regarding
Foster Child A’s father.
 Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief Administrator’s letter dated January 14,
2020 in response to Foster Parent A’s letter on November 22, 2019. The letter
summarized what was discussed at the meeting they had with Foster Parent A
on December 16, 2019, including parenting time with Foster Child A’s parents,
court and documents, family member visitation and communication.
 An email dated April 23, 2020 from Foster Care Worker 1 to Foster Parent A ,
which included a USP.
 An email thread dated May 29, 2020 including Foster Parent A and Foster Care
Worker 1 scheduling a meeting to discuss Foster Parent A’s concerns about
parenting time.
 Email threads dated June 10, 11, and 12, 2020 including Foster Parent A and
Foster Care Worker 1 discussing the parenting time schedule for the parents and
the purpose of supportive visitation for Foster Child A’s father.
 An email dated September 9, 2020 from Foster Care Worker 1 to Foster Parent
A informing them of what was discussed at a meeting Foster Care Worker 1 had
with MDHHS on September 9, 2020 and the parenting time schedule.
 FTM invitations from Foster Care Worker 1 to Foster Parent A on June 3, 2020,
September 14, 2020, and November 19, 2020.
 Foster Parent A signed the medical passport on October 30, 2020.
12

 Foster Parent A signed the PATP on May 2, 2020 and September 22, 2020.
Foster Parent A submitted a written addendum to the October 29, 2020 home
visit notes and PATP.
I reviewed Foster Child A’s case in MiSACWIS on April 13, 2021. Foster Parent A was
invited to FTMs that occurred on March 15, 2019, June 18, 2019, November 1, 2019,
June 10, 2020, September 14, 2020, and November 19, 2020. They attended the FTMs
on March 15, 2019, June 18, 2019, November 1, 2019, June 10, 2020, and September
14, 2020. Foster Parent A signed PATPs on April 9, 2019, August 5, 2019, January 24,
2020, May 7, 2020, and September 22, 2020.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the foster parent’s
role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan.
ANALYSIS: Based on the documents reviewed and the interviews
conducted, there is insufficient evidence to show that Ennis
Center for Children-Pontiac did not include Foster Parent 1 in
case planning or ensure that their input and written statements
were provided to the court. Foster Parent A provided their input
regarding the case via FTMs, written letters to the court and
Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac, emails and via a meeting that

CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED

A has not cooperated with the agency in the goal of reunification. Foster Parent A

the agency. The agency found Foster Parent A in non-compliance with Rules

that Foster Parent A was in non-compliance of licensing rule 9403 (a) as

9505 (2) were cited for the first special evaluation. She said noncompliance was

I reviewed Foster Child A’s case in MiSACWIS on April 13, 2021. I reviewed the

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(e) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
15

ANALYSIS: Per Rule 400.12327 (1) Special evaluation, an agency is
required to initiate a special evaluation, when the agency
receives information that relates to possible noncompliance with
any foster home rule. Based on the interviews conducted and
the documents reviewed, Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac
initiated a special evaluation against Foster Parent A when they
received information of possible noncompliance with foster
home rules by Foster Parent A. The agency reviewed several
documents and completed interviews to conclude that Foster
Parent A were in violation of foster home licensing rules. There
is no indication that the agency is in violation of the rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED

refused to sign the corrective action plan (CAP) for a special investigation.
INVESTIGATION:

Center for Children has delayed the annual foster care review, cancelled and then

I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief Administrator, Ennis Center for
Children - Pontiac Howell's Satellite Office Director, Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac

R 400.12324 Reevaluation.

ANALYSIS: Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac is in compliance with the rule.

ALLEGATION#7:
During COVID-19 closures, Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac made Foster Parent
1 transport Foster Child A to visits.
INVESTIGATION:
I reviewed the Complainant’s letter on February 23, 2021. The letter stated during the
COVID-19 closures and while the governor’s stay-at-home orders were in effect, Ennis
Center for Children made Foster Parent A transport Foster Child A to the exchange
point for Foster Child A to visit his father. The letter stated this was during a time when
persons of different households were not to visit one another.
I interviewed Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Chief Administrator, Ennis Center for
Children - Pontiac Howell's Satellite Office Director, Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac
Foster Care Worker 1, and Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care Supervisor 1
face-to-face on-site on March 04, 2021. Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac Foster Care
Worker 1 stated one of the days Foster Child A’s mother would visit with Foster Child A
was on a Friday, when Foster Child A’s father would typically have had Foster Child A
for parenting time. She said it was determined by Ennis Center for Children’s upper
management that a worker would always be present for all pick up and drop offs of
Foster Child A with her father. The father’s parenting time would begin following the
conclusion of the mother’s parenting time on Fridays. She said as licensed foster
parents, the agency expected Foster Parent A to transport Foster Child A to parenting
time and they would be reimbursed for mileage. Foster Care Worker 1 reported she
advised Foster Parent A that she could transport Foster Child A from Ennis Center for
Children’s Howell satellite office to the father’s home following the conclusion of the
mother’s parenting time so Foster Parent A did not have to make a second trip back to
Howell and since Foster Care Worker 1 would have to be present for the drop off. She
stated Foster Parent A refused her offer and said they did not feel comfortable with “a
stranger [Foster Care Worker 1] driving Foster Child A.” Foster Care Worker 1 said she
offered to assist with transportation for parenting time at the October 29, 2020 home
visit at Foster Parent A’s home and on October 30, 2020 at Ennis Center for Children,
however, they stated they would transport Foster Child A. Foster Care Worker 1
17

showed me a letter dated November 6, 2020 and written by Foster Parent A, which
stated Foster Child A needed to be transported by Foster Parent A.
Foster Care Worker 1 indicated that due to the agency’s COVID-19 restrictions, all
caregivers dropping and picking children up for parenting time must remain in their
vehicles during the parenting time. She said they may not sit in the waiting room, as to
minimize exposure and minimize the amount of people in the building. She reported
Foster Parent A was never inside the building during the drop offs, as Foster Child A
would be handed off to the mother outside the building while Foster Care Worker 1
watched. She said the room was void of all toys, properly disinfected, and all people
involved during the parenting time would have temperatures taken and they would
complete a questionnaire regarding COVID-19. Foster Care Worker 1 stated the
agency was unable to complete parenting time at Ingham county MDHHS as requested
by Foster Parent A due to MDHHS COVID-19 restrictions. She reported she was unable
to find parenting time locations near Ingham County to hold the visits due to COVID-19.
She said the mother lived in Genesee county and was thirty minutes from the Howell
satellite office and an hour away from Lansing. Due to this and COVID-19 restrictions,
Foster Care Worker 1 said parenting time was moved to Howell to best accommodate
Foster Child A’s mother.
I reviewed Foster Child A’s case in MiSACWIS on April 13, 2021. I reviewed a
document that included detailed dates and information describing issues the agency
had with Foster Parent A’s inability to participate in video visits with Foster Child A’s
father beginning in March 2020 when virtual parenting time was to occur until June
2020, when in-person parenting time could resume. There were times when Foster
Parent A said they were unable to connect to video software in order to conduct the
parenting time or not answering the telephone when Foster Child A’s father called for
parenting time.
I reviewed MDHHS Communication Issuance 20-032, which allowed parenting time to
occur via allowable alternatives including phone calls, Microsoft Teams, FaceTime,
Skype, Zoom, or other technology. I reviewed MDHHS Communication Issuance 20-
032* which stated beginning May 28, 2020 and no later than June 11, 2020, agencies
must resume in-person parenting time and sibling visits using locally developed plans.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(c) Provisions for visits between parents and children
except where parental rights have been terminated or when
there is a court determination that visits are detrimental to
the child.
18

ANALYSIS: Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac did not violate MDHHS
parenting time protocols that were issued during COVID-19. At
the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, parenting time for
Foster Child A was occurring virtually. Ennis Center for
Children-Pontiac documented issues that were occurring with
Foster Parent A being unable to complete virtual parenting time
with Foster Child A’s father. Once parenting time resumed to in-
person, Ennis Center for Children-Pontiac attempted to assist
Foster Parent A with transporting Foster Child A to parenting
time, however, they declined the assistance citing Foster Parent
A needed to transport Foster Child A to parenting time.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
